data.title: Missing Sublime Text command - select down to next auto complete suggestion
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to map Sublime Text default keyboard shortcuts to VS Code, I found that this feature is missing. 

The feature is select down to next auto complete suggestion. 

**Default Sublime Text keybindings**
Windows / Linux: <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd>
Mac: <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd>

![next_suggestion](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19566545/923397a2-969f-11e6-8120-132dab82ccd1.gif)

data.title: When hot exit restores neither files or untitled files from backup, no files that were open but not dirty are being restored
Missing Sublime Text command - expand selection to scope
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to map Sublime Text default keyboard shortcuts to VS Code, I found that this feature is missing. 

The feature is split selection into lines. 

**Default Sublime Text keybindings**
Windows / Linux: <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd>
Mac: <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd>

![expand_selection_by_scope](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19566165/22e0b55c-969e-11e6-83ec-2ee96c932345.gif)

Today an [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=letrieu.expand-region) exists that provides this feature. I believe we should bring this into the product.

data.title: Missing Sublime Text command - Change case of selection
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to map Sublime Text default keyboard shortcuts to VS Code, I found that this feature is missing. 

The feature is changing the case of the selection to upper and lower case. 

**Default Sublime Text keybindings**

| Case change | Windows / Linux | Mac |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Upper case | <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>u</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>u</kbd> |
| Lower case | <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>l</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>l</kbd> |

![upper_lower_case](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19565852/3481b5b4-969d-11e6-8458-42da4bdbbb63.gif)

Today an [extension exists](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wmaurer.change-case) with this functionality. I think this is a good feature to bring into the core of the product.

data.title: Missing Sublime Text command - select open editor by index
data.body:
While building this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to map Sublime Text default keyboard shortcuts to VS Code, I found that this feature is missing. 

The feature is selecting an open editor by index. 

**Default Sublime Text keybindings**

| Windows / Linux | Mac | Editor Index |
| --- | --- | --- |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>1</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>1</kbd> | 0 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>2</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>2</kbd> | 1 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>3</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>3</kbd> | 2 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>4</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>4</kbd> | 3 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>5</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>5</kbd> | 4 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>6</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>6</kbd> | 5 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>7</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>7</kbd> | 6 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>8</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>8</kbd> | 7 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>9</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>9</kbd> | 8 |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>0</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>0</kbd> | 9 |

![select_editor_by_index](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19565543/082bc2bc-969c-11e6-8fc6-16728efcbe36.gif)

data.title: The 'x' icon on the tab should be moved to the Left (from right)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.10.5

**Feature Suggestion**
1. The 'x' icon on the tab should be moved to the left (from right) so that its position is fixed relatively to the tab's origin (upper left corner), allowing users to close multiple tabs very quickly when the tab width are different.

**How to Replicate the Issue**
1. Create 8 dummy files with the file name length of 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45 characters.
2. Open and view them all with VSCode, you should now have 8 tabs opened horizontally side by side with different tab width.
3. Now starting from the left most tab, close each tab one by one VERY QUICKLY by clicking the 'x' icon on each tab.
4. You will find that you have to reposition your mouse cursor on each tab in order to hit the 'x' icon, which is tedious. This is because the 'x' position is not fixed with relative to the tab origin (upper left corner).

**Resolution**
1. By relocating the 'x' to the left of the tab, the 'x' position is now fixed relative to the tab origin. You can close all tabs very quickly without having to reposition your mouse cursor when the tab width are different.
2. UI mockup
![screen shot 2016-10-24 at 5 17 39 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15989924/19668646/0450edd2-9a0e-11e6-825e-f7c5e04ecbfe.png)
3. You can also try this out on Safari browser (x on the left) vs Chrome browser (x on the right).

data.title: problems console has warnings/errors of HEAD-file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T16:21:53.542Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: donjayamanne.githistory-0.1.0, formulahendry.code-runner-0.4.1, slevesque.vscode-hexdump-1.0.1, waderyan.gitblame-1.3.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open any css file with warnings/errors in code
2. modify file
3. open git / diff-view
4. open Problems console

Expected: Problems console has errors/warnings of modified file

Actual: Problems console has errors/warnings of modified file + HEAD-file

data.title: Support additional styling in stylesContributions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: all

Hello,

I'd like to know if it could be possible to add support for other CSS properties in the styleContributions code. Namely:
- text-transform
- text-decoration

(and why not all the ones mentionned in http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_text.asp , but that might be overkill).

For example, I'd like to have support for capitalization via style in order to develop a syntax style that looks like the PICO-8 UI:

![pico-8-code-300x298](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22177/19560911/b06c5466-96d6-11e6-8dd7-7dc4713e989a.png)

(note that in the usual code, all text is actually typed as lowercase and displays as uppercase.)

However the actual idea lies in the idea of supporting a slightly more extended set of css properties that could be customized via styles. This breaks the backward compatibility, though.

I can provide a PR, if required.

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/services/themes/electron-browser/stylesContributions.ts#L120

data.title: Do not send 'indexed' as a default filter when sending a Variable request
data.body:
Notice that `filter: "indexed"` is always sent as a part of `variables` request, no matter if a variable / scope supports indexing variables or not. By default `filter: undefined` should be sent.

fyi @weinand

data.title: Editor doesn't insert white spaces when formatting html files.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. 
Make sure that you set 
"editor.insertSpaces": true
in your workspace settings
2.
Make sure you are using indentation with spaces and indentation size 2 in my case.
3. 
Try to format html file

Expected result:
Editor should preserve white spaces as tabs.

Result:
Editor converts spaces to tabs. It should not.

Additional comment:
It works fine when saving typescript file for example.
The white spaces are preserved correctly.

- OS Version: Win7x64

data.title: Hot Exit: textFileServices.ts feedback
data.body:
Besides other feedback mentioned already (move backup logic into new backup service), there are some issues I noticed:

There is a public `backup()` method that does not seem to be used anywhere. 

doBackupAll() seems to be very complicated and possibly copied from another method. Do you need the source/target information really?

I do not understand this comment: `// Only remove the workspace from the backup service if it's not the last one or it's not dirty` 
Do we prevent hot exit for multiple windows with this check?

data.title: Fix typos and consistency issues
data.body: Minor fixes for typos and other consistency issues introduced in recent commits for Oct milestone.

data.title: MenuBar impossible to launch with Alt key on Ubuntu

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T15:43:46.054Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-42-generic, Ubuntu 16.04
- Extensions: alefragnani.Bookmarks-0.9.2, alefragnani.numbered-bookmarks-0.5.0, donjayamanne.githistory-0.1.0, ms-vscode.cpptools-0.9.2, waderyan.gitblame-1.3.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install on Ubuntu
2. Enter the `Alt` key which opens system menu bar

Since Ubuntu has integrated global menu there is natural that `Alt` keybinding opens search bar to find and execute commands. VSCode has own menu bar which I cannot launch using `Alt` keybinding and am unable to chenge that keybinding.

data.title: Hot Exit: backups are being discarded on shutdown even though file is not dirty?
data.body: I noticed that we seem to discard backups for files that are not dirty on shutdown. My understanding is that a non-dirty file cannot be in the backup DB at all, otherwise we have a bug?

data.title: Hot Exit: backup all ignores existing backups?
data.body: I noticed that on shutdown we just backup all dirty files but I think we should skip those files that already have an up to date backup stored (which is probably the typical case for all dirty files).

data.title: Hot Exit: Careful when you veto the shutdown from failing backups
data.body:
I notice that you seem to veto the shutdown if backups are failing, but you are not showing anything to the user. That is very tough to understand for a user why he cannot exit or close a window.

Suggest to add a message here or some handling from the backup service that should handle the shutdown phase.

data.title: Hot Exit: text file editor model does not discard a backup when saved
data.body: I do not see any call to discard backups for a file when it got saved. As mentioned before, I suggest to move this all into the new backup service that just tracks for model dirty and save events and you have a much easier life.
